Article.Abstract: To date, the pathogenesis of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in humans is still not well understood. SARS coronavirus (SARS-CoV)-specific CTL responses, in particular their magnitude and duration of postinfection immunity, have not been extensively studied. In this study, we found that heat-inactivated SARS-CoV elicited recall CTL responses to newly identified spike protein-derived epitopes (SSp-1, S978, and S1202) in peripheral blood of all HLA-A*0201(+) recovered SARS patients over 1 year postinfection. Intriguingly, heat-inactivated SARS-CoV elicited recall-like CTL responses to SSp-1 but not to S978, S1202, or dominant epitopes from several other human viruses in 5 of 36 (13.8%) HLA-A*0201(+) healthy donors without any contact history with SARS-CoV. SSp-1-specific CTLs expanded from memory T cells of both recovered SARS patients, and the five exceptional healthy donors shared a differentiated effector CTL phenotype, CD45RA(+)CCR7(-)CD62L(-), and expressed CCR5 and CD44. However, compared with the high avidity of SSp-1-specific CTLs derived from memory T cells of recovered SARS patients, SSp-1-specific CTLs from the five exceptional healthy donors were of low avidity, as determined by their rapid tetramer dissociation kinetics and reduced cytotoxic reactivity, IFN-gamma secretion, and intracellular production of IFN-gamma, TNF-alpha, perforin, and granzyme A. These results indicate that SARS-CoV infection induces strong and long-lasting CTL-mediated immunity in surviving SARS patients, and that cross-reactive memory T cells to SARS-CoV may exist in the T cell repertoire of a small subset of healthy individuals and can be reactivated by SARS-CoV infection.
Article.ArticleTitle: Response of memory CD8+ T cells to severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) coronavirus in recovered SARS patients and healthy individuals.
Article.Affiliations: Institute of Immunology, Second Military Medical University, Shanghai, China.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Heat-inactivated SARS-CoV stimulated PBMC from healthy donors produced IFNg and TNFa in response to the epitope, however, they produced a lower amount than PBMC from recovered SARS-CoV patients (also by ELISPOT). Healthy donor PBMC also produced perforin and granzyme A in lower levels than PBMC from recovered SARS patients.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: SARS patients were SARS-CoV-seropositive and 12-14 months post-recovery. PBMC were incubated with heat inactivated SARS-CoV to generate SARS-CoV CTLs.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Tetramer staining of CTLs from recovered SARS patients peaked 7 days after in vitro restimulation with heat inactivated SARS-CoV. Tetramer positive cells were also CD45RA+, CCR5+, CD44+, CD62L-, and CCR7-.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: SARS patients were SARS-CoV-seropositive and 12-14 months post-recovery. PBMC were incubated with heat inactivated SARS-CoV to generate SARS-CoV CTLs prior to tetramer staining.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: SSp-1 specific CTLs isolated by peptide-tetramer staining from recovered SARS patients lysed target cells presenting spike protein more efficiently than SSp-1 specific CTLs derived from healthy donors. These CTLS also produced IFNg ( ELISPOT) in response to epitope more efficiently than SSp-1 specific CTLs derived from healthy donors.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: SARS patients were SARS-CoV-seropositive and 12-14 months post-recovery. PBMC were restimulated with heat inactivated SARS-CoV.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Heat-inactivated SARS-CoV restimulated PBMC from recovered SARS patients produced a greater level of IFNg and TNFa in response to the epitope than did healthy donors (also by ELISPOT). PBMC from recovered SARS patients also produced perforin and granzyme A in higher levels than healthy donor PBMC.

Tetramer staining of CTLs from healthy donors was positive in 5 out of 36 subjects and peaked 7 days after in vitro stimulation with heat inactivated SARS-CoV. Tetramer binding was of lower avidity than the binding observed in CTLs derived from SARS recovered patients. Tetramer positive cells were also CD45RA+, CCR5+, CD44+, CD62L-, and CCR7-.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: PBMC were incubated with heat inactivated SARS-CoV to generate SARS-CoV CTLs prior to tetramer staining.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: SSp-1 specific CTLs isolated by peptide-tetramer staining from healthy donors lysed target cells presenting SARS-CoV spike protein less efficiently than CTLs derived from recovered SARS patients. These CTLs also produced IFNg (ELISPOT) in response to the epitope less efficiently than CTLs derived from recovered SARS patients.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: SARS patients were SARS-CoV-seropositive and 12-14 months post-recovery. PBMC were incubated with heat inactivated SARS-CoV.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Heat-inactivated SARS-CoV challenged PBMC from recovered SARS patients produced IFNg in response to the epitope, while healthy donor cells did not.
Heat-inactivated SARS-CoV stimulated PBMC from healthy donors did not produce IFNg in response to the epitope. PBMC from recovered SARS-CoV patients did produce IFNg in response to the epitope.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: SARS patients were SARS-CoV-seropositive and 12-14 months post-recovery. PBMC were incubated with heat inactivated SARS-CoV.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Heat-inactivated SARS-CoV restimulated PBMC from recovered SARS patients produced IFNg in response to the epitope, while healthy donor cells did not.
Heat-inactivated SARS-CoV stimulated PBMC from healthy donors did not produce IFNg in response to the epitope. PBMC from recovered SARS-CoV patients did produce IFNg in response to the epitope.
Heat-inactivated SARS-CoV stimulated PBMC from healthy donors did not produce IFNg in response to the epitope.
Heat-inactivated SARS-CoV stimulated PBMC from healthy donors did not produce IFNg in response to the epitope.
